Gorham v. Townsend, 191 Mass. 330 (1906).proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Gorham v. Townsend, 191 Mass. 330 (1906).support_reasoning: The opinion in Gorham v. Townsend concerns an action of contract based on an alleged promise of indemnity related to going bail, and addresses evidentiary and jury-instruction issues. It does not involve premises liability, negligence, hazardous property conditions, or maintenance of trees. Therefore, it does not support the proposition about a defendant’s negligence in failing to maintain a tree causing plaintiff’s injuries.
Gorham v. Townsend, 191 Mass. 330 (1906).relevant_excerpt: "This is an action of contract on an alleged promise of indemnity to save the plaintiff harmless if he would go bail with the defendant for one Freed. At the trial in the Superior Court, the jury returned a verdict for the plaintiff; and the case is before us on the defendant’s exceptions."

Davis v. O'Brien, 302 Mass. 156 (1939)..proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.

Ryan v. Cambridge, 328 Mass. 324 (1952)..proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Ryan v. Cambridge, 328 Mass. 324 (1952)..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the validity of a municipal garbage collection contract under a city charter provision requiring auditor certification. It does not address premises liability, tree maintenance, negligence, or personal injury. Therefore, it provides no support for a proposition about a defendant’s negligent failure to maintain a tree causing plaintiff’s injuries.
Ryan v. Cambridge, 328 Mass. 324 (1952)..relevant_excerpt: “On August 16, 1950, the plaintiff filed this bill in equity against the city of Somerville and its mayor, John M. Lynch, to have adjudged valid a contract awarded by the city to the plaintiff on December 14, 1949, for the collection of garbage in said city for five years. The defendants deny the validity of the contract. The judge found specially that the contract ‘did not contain certification by the city auditor as required by law,’ and entered a final decree adjudging that the contract is invalid…”

Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. C.raw_text: Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 307 F. Supp. 2d 289 (D. Mass. 2004).
Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. C.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. C.case_name: Fay v. Aetna Life Insurance & Annuity Co.
Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. C.support_reasoning: The Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co. opinion reproduced here does not involve any claim about a defendant’s negligent failure to maintain a tree or a hazardous condition caused by a tree. It concerns alleged misrepresentations and contract issues relating to a life insurance policy and the statute of limitations for those claims. Because the case does not address premises liability, negligent maintenance of property, or causation of injuries by a tree or similar hazard, it does not support the stated proposition.
Mahoney v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. C.relevant_excerpt: On May 16, 2001, William Fay, Sr., Kathleen Fay, and Frank Santangelo, in his capacity as Trustee of the Fay Insurance Trust, filed this Complaint against Aetna Life Insurance and Annuity Company (Aetna), and a former Aetna general manager, Gary Pflugfelder, alleging breach of contract, breach of the implied covenant of good faith and fair dealing, fraud and deceit, negligence, estoppel, and violation of G.L. c. 93A and c. 176D.... Plaintiffs maintain that Pflugfelder misrepresented the terms of a $6 million Aetna life insurance policy...

Mom's Laundry, Inc. v. Vill. Market of L.raw_text: Mom's Laundry, Inc. v. Vill. Market of Lynnfield, Inc., 415 Mass. 68 (1993).
Mom's Laundry, Inc. v. Vill. Market of L.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Mom's Laundry, Inc. v. Vill. Market of L.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns juvenile criminal procedure, indictments, and transfer hearings for juveniles charged with murder. It does not address negligence, premises liability, duties to maintain trees, or causation of injuries from hazardous property conditions. Therefore, it provides no support for the proposition about a defendant’s negligence in failing to maintain a tree on his property.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)..proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)..support_reasoning: The provided excerpt from Mounsey v. Ellard is a concurrence discussing the abolition of common‑law distinctions among licensees, invitees, and (possibly) trespassers for premises liability. It does not address any duty to maintain trees, hazardous tree conditions, or causal negligence related to tree maintenance. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific proposition about negligent failure to maintain a tree causing plaintiff’s injuries.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693 (1973)..relevant_excerpt: "The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a 'licensee' rather than an 'invitee,' or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. But footnote 7 seems to say that 'trespassers' stand apart, that that characterization is to remain decisive or highly influential."

Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.raw_text: Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 267 Mass. 501 (1929).
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.support_reasoning: The case involves a movie company’s negligent disposal and delivery of inherently dangerous scrap film, not a landowner’s failure to maintain a tree or other condition on real property. The court’s analysis concerns duties associated with inherently dangerous products, statutory fire-prevention regulations, and proximate cause, rather than premises liability or a duty to maintain trees. Therefore, the opinion does not support the proposition about negligent failure to maintain a tree on one’s property causing injury.
Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp., 26.relevant_excerpt: “Those cases are inapplicable to the case at bar because, apart from any negligence arising out of the delivery of an inherently dangerous article, without notice, to a person who had no actual knowledge of its dangerous potentialities, there rested on the defendant an additional legal duty to see that the scrap film was safely disposed of. On the evidence the jury could properly find that there had been a violation of § 23 of the regulations of the fire prevention commissioner relating to motion picture film.”

Salonen v. Packett, 453 Mass. 726 (2009).proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Salonen v. Packett, 453 Mass. 726 (2009).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt provided is a Massachusetts criminal case about heroin distribution, juror issues, motions for mistrial, and proof of a school-zone distance. It does not involve any facts or legal analysis concerning negligence, landowner duties, or failure to maintain a tree or other hazardous condition on property. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about a defendant’s negligence in failing to maintain a tree causing plaintiff’s injuries.
Salonen v. Packett, 453 Mass. 726 (2009).relevant_excerpt: The defendant was convicted by a Superior Court jury of distributing heroin in a school zone... On appeal to the Appeals Court, he claimed that his trial counsel was constitutionally ineffective... and the Commonwealth failed to establish the accuracy of the device used to measure the distance between the drug transaction and the school... We granted the defendant’s application for further appellate review, and now affirm the judgments.

Cousins v. O'Connell, 325 Mass. 230 (195.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Cousins v. O'Connell, 325 Mass. 230 (195.support_reasoning: The opinion in Cousins v. O'Connell concerns a contract dispute over payment for road construction work performed for a town and issues under the municipal finance statute, G.L. c. 44, § 31. It does not address premises liability, negligence, duty to maintain trees, or hazardous property conditions causing personal injury. Therefore, it provides no authority for the asserted negligence proposition and is being misused if cited for that purpose.
Cousins v. O'Connell, 325 Mass. 230 (195.relevant_excerpt: Pertinent evidence agreed to by the parties includes the following: At the annual town meeting in 1940 of the town of Southbridge (hereinafter called the town) it was voted “That the town raise and appropriate the sum of five thousand ($5,000) dollars to rebuild that part of Elm Street known as Lebanon Road from its junction with Brickyard Road southerly, the same to be taken from the tax levy of 1940.” On June 10, 1940, a contract was executed between the plaintiff and the defendant by the terms of which the plaintiff agreed to do certain work on the road in accordance with a schedule of prices set forth in the contract.

Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, In.raw_text: Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, Inc., 390 Mass. 6 (1983).
Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, In.proposition: Plaintiff alleges that Defendant was negligent in failing to maintain the tree on his property, causing a hazardous condition to exist, which directly resulted in the injuries suffered by Plaintiff.
Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, In.support_reasoning: The case concerns negligence by a liquor store in selling alcohol to a minor, leading to a drunk-driving death. It does not involve any allegation that a defendant failed to maintain a tree or created a hazardous condition via property maintenance. The legal principles addressed relate to vendor liability for unlawful alcohol sales and proximate cause, not premises liability for failure to maintain a tree, so it does not support the stated proposition.
Michnik-Zilberman v. Gordon's Liquor, In.relevant_excerpt: “The store asserts that liability extends to vendors of alcoholic beverages for injuries caused by their customers only when the sale of those beverages is to an intoxicated customer. We do not agree. It is the rule of this Commonwealth that negligence on the part of a seller or supplier of alcoholic beverages may be shown by a sale or the furnishing of those beverages to a minor… Thus, if a vendor fails to exercise due care and sells liquor to a minor, it is responsible for all proximately caused injuries.”
